title: Relates to penalties for the illegal shipment of cigarettes
summary: Relates to penalties for the illegal shipment of cigarettes and the authority of state and local authorities to bring actions to recover civil fines for such violations.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2170

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to amend the public health law, in relation to the shipment of
cigarettes

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

This bill would amend the Public Health Law provisions related to the
shipment of cigarettes by allowing local enforcement and injunctive
relief, and by providing clarifying language so that government
employees may conduct sting operations.

JUSTIFICATION:

The State's landmark cigarette shipment statute, which effectively
prohibits the retail sale of cigarettes through the mail or common
carriers, has withstood multiple attacks in courts. The statute
services both public health purposes of keeping cigarettes away from
minors and revenue integrity purposes by ensuring that taxes on
cigarettes are paid.

These amendments strengthen the statue in several ways. First, the
current wording of subdivision 1 provides an unintended defense to
government "sting" operations, as it provides that compliance with
the statute is not necessary when a government employee makes a
purchase otherwise prohibited by the statute, in the course of their
duties. Therefore, if a State or City worker were to conduct a sting
operation by purchasing cigarettes in violation of the statute, a
seller could have a defense that the law was not broken as the
official was purchasing the cigarettes in the course of their duties,
and that therefore compliance with the law was not needed. The bill
adds language in section 1 to correct this potential problem.

Further, Section 1 clarifies the civil penalty to be up to $5,000 per
violation or $100/pack of cigarettes shipped.

The amendments in Section two of the bill provide for more effective
enforcement, both through the injunctive relief provisions, and by
allowing local governments to enforce the statute and collect civil
penalties. Through these changes, maximum enforcement of the statute
will be ensured and repeated violators will be subject to injunctive
relief, rather than fines, which can often be carried as part of the
cost of doing business.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

S.2001/A.7326 of 2007-08 (Passed Assembly); S.5638-B of 2005-06
S.2324/A.1833 of 2009-10 (Passed Assembly)

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

Immediately.
